p: Overall, the exposure undergone by P. pinaster is largely increased in future climate scenarios, as the percentage of non-exposed populations decreases from 30.7% in current climate to 8.3% then (see Figs 2 and 3). However, this is mainly due to a higher abiotic exposure, as the rate of populations under both abiotic and biotic exposure is maintained between both periods. Our results point to a reduction in biotic exposure that is particularly important in the north-western side of the Iberian Peninsula (seed zones 1, 2 and 3; comparison Figs 2 and 3).
